dataset.title: Habitat availability estimates of lter 100m stream sites.

abstract.para: Habitat availability measurements were recorded biannually along with electrofishing (different data set) starting in late summer 1991. Data was collected each spring and late summer from 1991-1998, in order to examine changes in fish assemblage structure along the habitat gradient.

intellectualRights.para: Must adhere to the Coweeta LTER Data Policy (See http://coweeta.uga.edu/policies/data).

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CC2 - Ball Creek above weir - meter marks 780-890 | UBC - Upper Ball Creek - meter marks 2330-2430 | LBC - Lower Ball Creek - meter marks 4640-4747 | CC2 - Coweeta Creek - meter marks 5220-5320

abstract.para:
The Coweeta LTER Research Program has evolved since 1980 from a site-based to a site- and region-based project examining the effects of disturbance
and environmental gradients on biogeochemical cycling, and the underlying
watershed ecosystem processes that regulate and respond to those cycles.
The objective for the 2002-2008 research is to advance scientific
understanding of the spatial, temporal, and decision-making components of
land use and land-use change in the southern Appalachian Mountains over the
last 200 years, and forecast patterns into the future 30 years. This will
be accomplished by addressing ecological and socioeconomic aspects of
land-use change while continuing long-term studies of environmental
gradients and natural disturbance regimes. The result will be a more
complete understanding of ecological dynamics in the southern Appalachian
Mountains that makes possible the development of reasonable forecasts of
its future ecological state. | The guiding hypothesis for the proposed research is that the frequency, intensity, and extent of land use represents human decision-making in
response to socioeconomic and bio-geophysical conditions with consequences
that cascade through ecosystems. The research activities are organized
into three initiatives: (1) Characterization of the Socio-Natural Template,
(2) Ecosystem Responses to the Socio-Natural Template, and (3) Forecasting
Ecosystem Responses to Changes in the Socio-Natural Template. The
integrated scientific research will provide both a description as well as
an explanation of the underlying causes of land use and the consequences of
land-use change for southern Appalachian ecosystems and society. It thus
recognizes the complexity of land use as a process and the research needs
as defined in the LTER Program and the broader scientific community.

funding.para: National Science Foundation. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year when sample was collected
Month when sample was collected
Day when sample was collected
CRK stream section (100m) sampled . site codes

codeDefinition.definition: Ball Creek above weir 27 approx. 100m above weir 27.
Upper Ball Creek approx. 100m above old weir 20.
Lower BAll Creek approx. 60m above weir 9
Coweeta Creek starts at confluence of Ball Creek and Shope Fork

attribute.attributeDefinition: or labeled DISTFLAG. the distance measured (m) from the transect stake on the right bank to the corresponding transect stake on the left bank to nearest 0.1 meter
the site is marked along each bank in 5 m intervals refers to mter mark starting at the downstream end of the site

textDomain.definition: the site is marked along each bank in 5 m intervals refers to mter mark starting at the downstream end of the site

attribute.attributeDefinition: or labeled WW_LT. 1991 to 1997. the measured distance along the transect line from the stake along the left bank to the wetted width on the left bank to nearest 0.1 meter. 1997 to present is the measured distance along the transect line for a given transect from the right bank stake to the wetted width on the left bank to nearest 0.1 meter
or labeled WW_RT. the measured distance along the transect line for a given transect from the right bank stake to the wetted width on the right bank to nearest 0.1 meter

whole meter mark points along transect line where samples are taken starting from right bank stake. Habitat availability estimates are done along this line recording the meter mark where the sample is made.

textDomain.definition: whole meter mark points along transect line where samples are taken starting from right bank stake. Habitat availability estimates are done along this line recording the meter mark where the sample is made.

attribute.attributeDefinition: measured with a meter stick to nearest cm
AVCV average current velocity measured in cm/s with a Marsh McBirney 201 flow meter.
the estimated percent of bedrock (Imbedded rock) made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location.
the estimated percent of sand (material less than 0.2 cm) made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location
the estimated percent of silt (Material capable of suspension in water column) made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location
the estimated percent of boulder (> = 30cm) made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location
the estimated percent of cobble (less than 30 cm and bigger than 2.5 cm) made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location
the estimated percent of debris (Wood or leafy matter)made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location
the estimated percent of gravel (less than 2.5 cm and bigger than 0.2 cm)made by a trained observer using a 20 x 20 cm viewer directly above the sample location
TEMPerature of the water temperature in C degrees.

From 1991 to 1993, if sample point lands on exposed substrate within the stream the point if classified as EXP. From 1994 to 1998, if sample point is outside stream wetted width or lands on exposed substrate within the stream the point if classified as to the majority substrate or composite substrate there. Substrate codes are first 2 letters of substrate category
